content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and easy contribution with a well phrased statement. All modes can be fun with this one.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks clean and easy to me. Nice contribution! :)

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I see again this problem about string  badly used . 

In C# I have to control how many digit compose a number , put this number in a new declaration like this :string s0 = x.substring(number character who began the number , number of digit who compose the digit) After that I have to use int i0 = Int32.Parse(s0); who convert a string to int 
All this is for 1 number

That represent a big loss of time .And this problem certainly exist for Java , C, C++and many other language

You have to change the line 2 in the stub

I'm sorry but I have to reject this contribution

Je vois encore ce problème a propos de string  dans le stub mal utilisé.

En C# Je dois controler combien de chiffre controle un nombre , mettre ce nombre dans une nouvelle déclaration pour ça:string s0 = x.substring(numero du caractère commencent le nombre , nombre de chiffre composant le nombre) Après je dois utiliser int i0 = Int32.Parse(s0); qui convertir un string en int.

Tous ça pour un seul nombre

Cela représente une grosse perte de temps et ce problème existe certainement dans Java , C , C++ et bien d'autres langage

Tu dois changer la ligne 2 dans le stub

Je suis désolé mais je dois rejeter cette contribution

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The description is very clear and the exercise is quite simple, very good for beginners.
Nice and easy contribution. I have nothing to complain. I would approve ASAP.
Thanks :) it's fairly easy, that's why it's only Code size and reverse. Do you think I should also add it to the speed mode ?
I don't see how this is a problem of the contribution and not of C#.
Exactly, if your language is not suited for the job, it's not my fault. But I can understand how it might not be fair.

I don't think the players have to guess what his the best language for resolve a problem. I think the line
loopline <number in line> <int> 

in the stub will be most fair for players .

I also have the impression that the person I talk about this problem only know python.
Unfortunetely the exercice isn't suppose to be resolve only in python
I'll see what I can do once I have the time

I just tested this contribution with C#. There is no need for substring. 
Take a look here: https://dotnetfiddle.net/al7ZPL

Also: There are always pros and cons when it comes to programming languages. One big con of C# is its bulkiness. It takes more time to progam with it that with for example Python. You will probably alos have way worse chances to win in shortest-mode with C#. Those are not problems of the contribution but of the choice of the programming language.

In real life, it is completely normal to see a string of words without knowing their number before reading them.

I do not know what the best practice is, but it is quite natural that some languages are better suited to certain problems than others. Although I try to solve everything I see here in Haskell, I switch to Perl or something like that when I see a problem that requires regular expressions.

Making sure that a problem is equally difficult in any language seems almost impossible to me.
Definetly. And I saw you already did that. Nice! :)
